newsitem.title: CANADA: Bid target Wascana makes large 1996 gains.
newsitem.headline: Bid target Wascana makes large 1996 gains.

text.p: Wascana Energy Inc, target of a C$1.7-billion takeover bid from Talisman Energy Inc, on Thursday reported record results for 1996 and suggested it was not about to go down without a fight.
"Wascana successfully produced record cash flow, earnings and oil volumes in 1996," Wascana chief executive officer Frank Proto said in a statement.
"The results announced today confirm that Wascana has turned around, and that the best years for shareholders lie ahead as we build on our 1996 success," Proto said.
Regina, Saskatchewan-based Wascana said its earnings last year grew to C$35 million, or C$0.43 a share, compared to restated earnings in 1995 of C$600,000 or C$0.01 a share.
Cash flow was C$215 million or C$2.61 a share in 1996, up from C$191 million or C$2.36 a share the year before.
Crude oil production averaged 51,400 barrels a day in 1996 and natural gas output reached 200 million cubic feet per day.
Wascana announced its year-end results on the same day as Talisman, which also reported a record financial and operating performance for the year.
Calgary-based Talisman plans to offer C$18.50 cash or 0.41 of a Talisman share for each share of Wascana, a former Saskatchewan government-owned company known for heavy oil production and reserves.
Talisman has yet to mail its offer document for the deal, which would be the largest transaction in Canada's energy sector in three years.
But Wascana's future growth plans -- including increased capital spending for the year -- suggested the company was not about roll over.
"I look forward to the coming debate about the dynamic future of Wascana Energy and I am optimistic that we will, through the process, ensure the optimal result for our shareholders," Proto said.
Wascana said its board of directors would review the bid and make a recommendation to shareholders after the circular was received from Talisman.
"We haven't got an offer yet, so this company continues to move forward," Wascana spokesman Tim Jeffery said in a telephone interview from Regina.
